sect1.title: Partitioning
sect1.para: &sles4sap; creates the partitioning table in two stages:

listitem.para: (during the installation of the operating system)
(during the installation of the SAP product)

sect2.title: Partitioning for the Operating System (stage 1)
sect2.para: During the installation of the operating system, partitions for the operating system are created.
A logical volume group (LVG) named /dev/system will be created. This LVG contains two logical volumes (LVs):

listitem.para: /dev/system/root (by default: 60 GB to account for the operating system and SAP media; even on virtualized installations, this should not be set smaller than 5 GB)
listitem.remark: 5GB min is from old guide. Only double-check with varkoly, seemed fine to pschinagl. - sknorr, 2016-01-21

listitem.para: /dev/system/swap (by default: 2 GB, avoid setting a smaller size)

sect2.para: Additionally, a boot or UEFI partition will be created as necessary.

sect2.title: Partitioning for the SAP System (stage 2)
sect2.para: The partitioning for the SAP system is done by the &sapwiz; and can only take place after the operating system has been installed. That means the partitions are created either during the installation workflow after the reboot or in the running system.
Depending on the product you are installing and your particular use case, the amount of hard disk space necessary can vary. Consider the following minimal amounts:

formalpara.title: &netweaver;
formalpara.para: At least 80 GB of hard disk space are necessary.

formalpara.title: &hana;
formalpara.para: At least 60 GB of hard disk space are necessary.

sect2.para: Partitioning for the SAP system is controlled by the files from the directory /usr/share/YaST2/include/sap-installation-wizard/. Usually, base_partitioning.xml will be used. When installing &hana; on certified hardware, other files will be chosen, as defined in /etc/sap-installation-wizard.xml. Here, the content of the element partitioning is decisive.
If the installation is, for example, based on HA or a distributed database, no partitioning is needed. In this case, partitioning is set to NO, the file base_partitioning.xml is used.
sect2.remark: Not happy with "based on HA"... Can sth. be based on HA? Would "high-availability system" or so work? According to pschinagl, this refers to the SAP app installation type that can be chosen SIW - sknorr, 2016-01-25
The old guide claimed that base_partitioning.xml does nothing. True? Does not really look like it, but I am no expert. Are base_part and NO really the same thing? - sknorr, 2016-01-25
sect2.para: The files that control partitioning are &ay; control files that contain a partitioning section only. However, these files allow using several extensions to the &ay; format:

listitem.para: If the partitioning_defined tag is set to true, the partitioning will be performed without any user interaction.
By default, this is only used when creating &hana; file systems on systems certified for &hana; (such as from Dell, Fujitsu, HP, IBM, or Lenovo).

For every partition, you can specify the size_min tag. The size value can be given as a string in the format of RAM*N. This way you can specify how large the partition should minimally be (N times the size of the available memory (RAM)).

procedure.title: Creating a Custom SAP Partitioning Setup
procedure.para: The steps below illustrates how to create a partitioning setup for TREX. However, creating a partitioning setup for other applications works analogously.

step.para: In /usr/share/YaST2/include/sap-installation-wizard/, create a new XML file. Name it TREX_partitioning.xml, for example.
Copy the content of base_partitioning.xml to your new file and adapt the new file to your needs.
Finally, adapt /etc/sap-installation-wizard.xml to include your custom file. In the listitem for TREX, insert the following line:

important.title: Do Not Edit base_partitioning.xml
important.para: Do not edit base_partitioning.xml directly. With the next update, this file will be overridden.
